page.title: 14BOYS GRAVE
page.content: At a crossroads near Kentford on a small plot of land is the grave of Joseph the unknown gypsy boy. Joseph thought he had lost one of the sheep that he was looking after. His employer accused him of sheep stealing. The boy was so upset that he hanged himself. When the farmer counted the sheep he found that non were missing. As was usual with gypsies the boy was buried at a crossroads. For many years passing gypsies cared for the grave but recently Mrs. Angela Redshaw placed a wooden cross and puts fresh flowers on the grave every week. If you go past the little boys grave it is supposed to be lucky to throw some silver onto it. Another superstition is that if some flowers bloom on the little boys grave in spring a Newmarket horse will win the Derby.
